title: Am i responsible for my ex-wife's medical debt in california?
question: My ex-wife has an unpaid medical bill from 5 years ago that's showing up on my credit report. We were still married at the time she received the treatment but we were not living together. Am i still liable for this debt and if not how can get it removed from my credit report?
question_tags: Divorce,Alternatives to divorce,Legal separation and divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Divorce and medical debt,Community property in divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Spousal debt,Marriage
answers:
Review California Family Code section 910. Debts incurred after physical separation are the separate debts of each spouse, with the exception of some "necessities of life."

Do not pay a penny. That will re-start the Statute of Limitations and revive the debt. As it stands now, they cannot successfully sue you if file an Answer and allege the running of the Statute of Limitations. As to your credit, send a written dispute to each credit reporting agency that is reporting the account.
Since California is a community property state, unless you were legally separated at the time that she received the treatment, you would be liable.

You were not living together, but did you or her intend to eventually get back together or was it completely over at that time?

There may be some loophole to getting out of that particular debt but it may be a lot of trouble. I'd just take the credit hit.
